conclusion: To determine whether the two cars collide before or after 20 seconds of braking, we need to analyze the velocity-time (v-t) graph provided.
The graph shows the velocities of Car A and Car B over time. Car A starts at a higher velocity (25 m/s) and decreases linearly. Car B starts at a lower velocity (15 m/s) and also decreases linearly.

premise: Car A starts at 25 m/s and decreases to 0 m/s over 30 seconds.
Car B starts at 15 m/s and decreases to 0 m/s over 30 seconds.
Velocity function for Car A: v_A(t) = 25 - (5/6)t
conclusion: Position function for Car A: s_A(t) = 25t - (5/12)t²

premise: Velocity function for Car B: v_B(t) = 15 - (1/2)t
conclusion: Position function for Car B: s_B(t) = 15t - (1/4)t²

premise: The cars collide when s_A(t) = s_B(t).

conclusion: The cars collide at t = 60 seconds.

conclusion: Since 60 seconds is greater than 20 seconds, the collision occurs after 20 seconds of braking.
